forumNotes.author: Sha0
forumNotes.content: There is neither a **MEMDISK** nor a **GRUB4DOS memory-mapped disk** driver for Linux at this time. Sorry, but you cannot access RAM discs of this nature (loaded from **.ISO** s) from Linux. Maybe some day. That is, if your Linux distributions are trying to load files from the CD/DVD, it will not work. If everything they need is contained in just the kernel and "initrd," then that's fine and should succeed.

Ok, but these disks would load as single Boot USB's \& as CD's...so will it make a difference having GRUB4DOS at the front??

forumNotes.author: Sha0
forumNotes.content: The difference is not GRUB4DOS in particular, it is that the .ISOs are not physical disc drives attached to the computer. GRUB4DOS (or MEMDISK) can hook the **BIOS INTerrupt 0x13** service and provide the virtual disk to consumers, but Linux is not (and Windows is not) an INT 0x13 consumer. Linux has drivers which look for CD/DVD drives. Since your .ISO is just a region of memory, there isn't a corresponding CD/DVD drive to be found. You could try posting a directory listing of one of these .ISOs and it might be obvious whether or not everything you need is contained in the kernel+initrd.
